Flash graphene discovered by rice university turns trash into graphene, a 2D Martial 200X stronger than steel, that's also a super conductor at room temperatures and is highly efficient at transferring heat. It can also be added to everything from concrete to plastics. In most cases making the material stronger but sometimes it's other properties carry over as well. In the case of concrete, it cools faster, and lasts longer. I've got more info if you guys wanna make a video about it.

Cooling/preserving the skins for transport may be costly, but it seems reasonable to sell your byproducts.  It could possibly be made into cat food, and almost certainly into a component of sea roach rations (food for aquacultured shrimp) or fertilizer.  If the FL orange juice industry bothers to collect the rinds (after the much more valuable essential oils are removed for separate processing and sale) as a low cost food for cattle, surely the seafood industry can find ways to recycle byproducts.  Many probably do so already.

Ive got a fast fact anti-microbial related - did you know that the widely used herbicide glyphosate is likely conferring anti-bacterial resistance in soil bacteria (which can include anthrax!). The way in which glyphosate kills non-resistant plants, bacteria and fungi is by preventing an enzyme functioning that build’s the organism’s immune system - this is extremely similar to the way in which penecilin kills bacteria. Scientists found that some bacteria that were developing resistance to glyphosate were also developing resistance to anti-biotics! (This was a part of my dissertation on the growing use of glyphosate).

The article investigating the link was by Van Bruggen et al., 2018. “Environmental and health effects of the herbicide glyphosate”
